member.name: T:Neon.Collections.Bits
member.summary: Implements an efficient array of boolean values that can also perform bit oriented operations such as AND, OR, NOT, XOR.

remarks.note: This class is similar to the .NET class. The main difference is that this class serializes the bits to a byte array as you'd expect, with bit zero being the most significant bit of the first byte, bit one being the second significant bit, etc. The class serializes the first bit to the least significant bit of the first byte.
remarks.para: A bitmap encodes internally as an array of 32-bit integers which is much more memory efficent than how the .NET Framework would encode an array of boolean values. Use the constructor to create a zeroed bitmap with the specified number of bits, to initialize the bitmap from a boolean array, or to create a bitmap from a string of ones and zeros, and to load a bitmap from a byte array serialized by a previous call to .

You can use the indexer to get/set specific bits in the bitmap. Note that all indexes are zero-based. sets the specified range of bits to zero, sets the specified range of bits to one, and and sets all bits to the appropriate value. can be used to resize a bitmap.
The class implements the following bitwise operations: , , , , , and . Note that the lengths of the two bitmaps passed to binary operations must be the same.

returns a copy of the bitmap and converts the bitmap into a boolean array. The and properties can be used to determine if a bitmap is all zeros or ones and can be used to determine whether two bitmaps are the same. renders the bitmap as a string of 1s and 0s.
This class also defines explict casts for converting to and from a string of ones and zeros and also defines the bitwise ||, &, ~ and ^, <<, and >> operators.

member.name: T:Neon.Common.BlockArray
member.summary: Implements an array of instances.

remarks.para: The purpose of is to avoid performance robbing buffer reallocations and copies and large obvject heap applications as can happen with extensive use of the class. Rather than doing I/O to a single large buffer, the provides the underlying functionality for spreading I/O across multiple blocks. This avoids any need to reallocate and copy a large buffer as the stream grows an also tends to allocate consistently sized memory blocks, making life easier for the memory allocator.
This class is pretty flexible. Blocks can be explicitly added and removed from the class or the , , or methods can be used have the class handle block management.

The and properties are used by the internal block management methods when allocating new blocks. defaults to 512 and specifies the size of new blocks. defaults to 0. New blocks will have their field set to .

BlockOffset provides for some tricky performance optimizations. A common situation in network protocols is the need to fragment serialized data across multiple data packets with fixed sized headers. Setting BlockOffset to the size of the fixed header will reserve these bytes at the beginning of each block. The data can be serialized into the array and then afterwards, the headers can be written manually into each block. This technique can avoid lots of buffer copying.

para.note: You should call after directly modifying the or properties of any of the blocks in the array. It is not necessary to call this for changes to the Block.Buffer array.

summary.para: Thrown by and when the type for the exception identified by doesn't exist in the current .

This can happen when a remote process throws an exception from an assembly it references but is not referenced by the calling process. In these cases, you'll need to catch this exception and then examine the property to identify the exception and potentially the property as well.

member.name: T:Neon.Common.CommandLine
member.summary: Performs common operations on application a DOS or Linux command line.

remarks.para: Command lines may consist of zero or more items. Items that begin with the dash (-) character are considered to be command line options. Items that begin with an at sign (@) can be considered to be response files, and all other items are considered to be command line arguments.
remarks.note: The "-" and "--" items (without an option name are considered arguments, not options.
remarks.para: The static method can be used to process response files specified in a command line. Response files are specified by prepending a '@' character to the name of a text file and then treating each line of the file as a command line item.
The static method can be used to expand file names with wildcard characters into the set of actual files that match the pattern.
The class can also handles parsing of items as command line options.
remarks.code: -<option name>[=<value>]
remarks.para: will be parsed into name/value pairs and will be available for lookup via the string keyed indexer. Options that specify no value will be assigned an empty string value.
remarks.note: Command line option names are case sensitive.
remarks.para: The class will also make all command line items available via the integer keyed indexer which will return items based on their position on the command line and also via the property. Command line items that are not command, are available via the property. Options can be looked up via the and overrides.
also supports the definition of long and short forms of options with optional default values using the method. This associates one or more option names with an optional default value.
You can use this easily implement the short and long forms of options as well as to centralize the specification of option default values.
remarks.note: This class assumes that the position of command line options doesn't matter, which is somewhat simplistic. In particular, the method actually relocates all of the options to the beginning of the shifted command line.

member.name: M:Neon.Common.CommandLine.ExpandFiles(System.String[])
member.summary: Expands the command line by processing items beginning with '@' as input files.

remarks.para: Command line items will be assumed to specify a text file name after the '@'. This file will be read and each non-empty line of text will be inserted as a command line parameter.
Lines of text whose first non-whitespace character is a pound sign (#) will be ignored as comments.

Command line parameters may also span multiple lines by beginning the parameter with a line of text begininning with "{{" and finishing it with a line of text containing "}}". In this case, the command line parameter will be set to the text between the {{...}} with any CRLF sequences replaced by a single space.
Here's an example:
This will be parsed as three command line parameters: -param1=aaa, -param2=bbb, and -param3=hello world

member.exception: Thrown if there's a problem opening an "@" input file.
Thrown if there's an error parsing an "@" input file.

member.name: T:Neon.Common.ExceptionResult
member.summary: Used to marshal a possible exception from a remote process to the local caller. Use this type for remote methods that return void or the derived type for remote methods that return a result.

remarks.note: This is typically be used internally by frameworks like Neon.Cadence to bring exception handling functionality when calling remote processes (like workflows and activities in that case).
remarks.para: This works by setting the property to the fully qualified name of the exception type and to the exception message (which may be null) in the remote process and then serializing the instance to JSON or some other format to be transmitted back to the caller.

The local caller will then call which will attempt to rethrow the exception with the same . This is accomplished by reflecting all assemblies currently loaded in the looking for exception types. Exception types that have a default constructor or constructors with a string message parameter or a message and inner exception message parameters will be cached internally in a dictionary that maps the type name to the exception type.
If can locate a local exception type that has a conforming constructor, then that exception type will be thrown with the . A will be thrown instead, if a conforming local exception doesn't exist.

member.summary: Set to the local exception's default constructor (if any).

member.summary: Set to the local exception's constructor that accepts a single string message argument (if any).

member.summary: Set to the local exception's constructor that accepts tring message and inner exception arguments (if any).

member.summary: Throws a local exception type, including the message passed.

member.name: T:Neon.Common.GlobPattern
member.summary: Implements a very simple glob matcher inspired by the GitHub .gitignore patterns described here.

remarks.para: The current implementation is somewhat limited compared to that for .gitignore:

list.item: Only "*" and "**" wildcard chacacters are allowed. "!" and "[..]" are not recognized.

remarks.note: This class works only for file paths using either Linux style forward slashes (/) or Windows style backslashes by converting any backslashes to forward slashes in before performing the match. The handles forward slash matching only.

member.name: T:Neon.Common.ILabeled
member.summary: Used by to retrieve the label dictionary for a specific item. Labels are simply key/value pairs assigned to an object and can be used to select items based on their assigned labels.

member.name: M:Neon.Common.ILabeled.GetLabels
member.summary: Returns the label dictionary for the instance. These are simply key/value pairs where the key is the label name. You may return null to indicate that there are not labels.
member.remarks: Label names may be treated as case sensitive or insentive based on how the underlying dictionary returned was constructed. Generally though, labels are considered to be case insensitive so you should probably use when constructing your dictionaries.

summary.para: This interface combines the capabilities of and to define an object that can dynamically add and remove service implementations. See the default implementation for more information.
summary.note: Implementations must be thread-safe.

summary.para: Implements a Kubernetes compatible general purpose label-based selector mechanism that can select a set of items from a collection based on the set of labels assigned to each item. This class supports some simple fixed query methods as well as a simple text-based query language.
This is suitable for operations like selecting Kubernetes related items by labels or annotations.

remarks.para: This class supports Kubernetes style label selectors:

For this to work, your type will need to implement the interface and its which returns a string/string dictionary holding that items labels. Then you can construct a selector instance via , passing your set of labeled items. Then you can call , , and to select items based on their labels and one ore more label conditions to be satisified.

note.para: Kubernetes labels are key/value pairs. Valid label keys have two segments: an optional prefix and name, separated by a slash (/). The name segment is required and must be 63 characters or less, beginning and ending with an alphanumeric character ([a-z0-9A-Z]) with dashes (-), underscores (_), dots (.), and alphanumerics between. The prefix is optional. If specified, the prefix must be a DNS subdomain: a series of DNS labels separated by dots (.), not longer than 253 characters in total, followed by a slash (/).

If the prefix is omitted, the label Key is presumed to be private to the user. Automated system components (e.g. kube-scheduler, kube-controller-manager, kube-apiserver, kubectl, or other third-party automation) which add labels to end-user objects must specify a prefix.
The kubernetes.io/ and k8s.io/ prefixes are reserved for Kubernetes core components.
Valid label values must be 63 characters or less and must be empty or begin and end with an alphanumeric character ([a-z0-9A-Z]) with dashes (-), underscores (_), dots (.), and alphanumerics between.

Label Names: must conform to the Kubernetes standard and will be treated as case sensitive or insensitive based on how the underlying dictionary returned was constructed. Generally though, labels are considered to be case insensitive so you should probably use when constructing the dictionaries returned by your item's method.
Label names must conform to the Kubernetes conventions by default but this can be relaxed by passing an option to the constructor.

remarks.note: Label Values: are considered to be case senstive by default but this can be customized via the constructor.
See for a description of the label selector language.
You may use the static and methods to explicity confirm that label keys and values satisfy the Kubernetes conventions.

member.summary: Returns the set of items that satisfy a label selector.
member.returns: The set of items whose meet the query requirements.
member.exception: Thrown when the label selector is not valid.

remarks.para: This class supports Kubernetes style label selectors:

Label selectors must include zero or more label conditions separated by commas. All label conditions must be satisfied for an item to be selected. The conditions are essentially AND-ed together. We'll support two basic types of label conditions: equality/inequality and set based.
remarks.note: A null or empty simply returns all items.
remarks.code: [label] = [value] [label] == [value] [label] != [value]
remarks.para: The first two examples two compare label value equality and the last compares for inequality. Note that it is not currently possible to compare an empty or null string.
remarks.code: [label] in ([value1], [value2],,...) notin([value1], [value2],...) [label] ![label]
remarks.para: The first example selects items if they have a label with any of the values listed and the second selects items that have the label that doesn't have any of the values. The last two examples select items when they have or don't have a label, regardless of its value.
remarks.note: The in and notin operators both require that the item have the target label for a match.

Case Sensitivity: Label name lookups are actually determined by the dictionary returned by each item. .NET string dictionaries are typically case sensitive by default but you can change this behavior by having your item implementations construct case insenstive dictionaries. By default, this class performs case insensitive comparisions for label values. You can override this by passing to the constructor.

note.para: Label Name Constraints: Label keys are checked to ensure that they match Kubernetes conventions by default. You can override this by passing to the constructor.
Label Value Constraints: Label values are also checked to ensure that they match Kubernetes conventions by default. This behavior can also be overriden by passing to the constructor.

member.name: T:Neon.Common.ServiceContainer
member.summary: This class combines the capabilities of a and into a single object that implements the combined interface.

remarks.para: The design of and seems somewhat limited. This assumes that applications explicitly initialize a instance during startup and then call BuildServiceProvider() to return the that can actually be used to find a service at runtime.

This works fine for lots of applications, but with a framework like Neon, it is useful to have a global service provider that allows the client to register default services for applications that are not coded to be aware of dependency injection. The problem with the Microsoft DependencyInjection design is that additional services registered after a BuildServiceProvider() call will not be returned by the service provider.
This class combines both these capabilities into a single class such that services can be registered and located dynamically without ever having to call BuildServiceProvider().
remarks.note: The BuildServiceProvider() extension methods still work the same and return only a point-in-time snapshot of the services. You may not need to call these though, because you can call directly.

member.name: P:Neon.Common.NeonHelper.ServiceContainer
member.summary: The root dependency injection service container used by Neon class libraries. and applications.

remarks.para: This instance implements both the and interfaces and supports adding, removing, and locating services over the lifetime of the application. This is more flexible than the default Microsoft injection pattern, where services are added to an at startup and then a read-only snapshot is taken via a BuildServiceProvider() call that is used throughout the remaining application lifespan.
This is implemented by a by default. It is possible to replace this very early during application initialization but the default implementation should suffice for most purposes.

member.summary: Starts a new to perform an action.

param.name: maxStackSize
param.para: Optionally specifies the maximum stack size, in bytes, to be used by the thread, or 0 to use the default maximum stack size specified in the header for the executable. Important for partially trusted code, is ignored if it is greater than the default stack size. No exception is thrown in theis case.
This defaults to 0 which generally means the stack size will be limited to 1 MiB for 32-bit applications or 4 MiB for 64-bit applications.

member.name: M:Neon.Common.NeonHelper.ExpandTabs(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Expands any embedded TAB (\t) characters in the string passed into spaces such that the tab stops will be formatted correctly.
member.param: Optionally expands TABs into spaces when greater than zero or converts a series of leading spaces into tabs if less than zero. This defaults to 4.

remarks.note: If the string passed includes line ending characters (CR or LF) then the output will include line endings for every line, including the last one.
remarks.para: A positive does what you'd expect by converting spaces in the string into TABs such that the tab stops align to the value passed. This works a bit differently for negative values.

A negative indicates that leading spaces in each line will be converted into TABs. A value of -1 indicates that each leading two spaces will bve converted into a TAB, a value of -2 indicates that each leading 2 spaces will be converted into a TAB, and so on.
Conversion to TABs will cease when the first non space is ecountered and any odd number of spaces remaining will be included in the output.

member.name: M:Neon.Common.NeonHelper.StripFileScheme(System.String)
member.summary: Removes a file:// scheme from the path URI if this is scheme is present. The result will be a valid file system path.

note.para: This method behaves slightly differently when running on Windows and when running on Unix/Linux. On Windows, file URIs are absolute file paths of the form:
To convert this into a valid file system path this method strips the file:// scheme and the following forward slash. On Unix/Linux, file URIs will have the form:
In this case, the forward shlash following the file:// scheme is part of the file system path and will not be removed.

member.summary: Used for implementing unit tests against the method. will call this action when it's non-null passing the file path, rather than actually opening the file in an editor. The handler can then simulate editing the file.

member.name: M:Neon.Common.NeonHelper.OpenEditor(System.String)
member.summary: Launches the platform text editor to create or edit a file.

remarks.para: This method will launch the editor specified in the EDITOR environment variable otherwise it will launch NotePad on Windows and Vim on Linux and OS/X. EDITOR should be set to the command line used to launch the editor with special $FILE parameter. This will be replaced with the path to the file being edited.
remarks.note: We'll simply append the file path if $FILE isn't found in the EDITOR environment variable.
remarks.para: This method will block until the editor is closed.
remarks.note: For unit testing, you may set to an action that will simulate editing the file. This action will be called instead of actually opening an editor when set.

summary.para: This method may be called to ensure that the Neon.Common assembly is required at compile in a project that doesn't reference Neon.Common. The method does nothing.
summary.note: A call to this is currently included by Neon.ModelGen to ensure that the enclosing project references Neon.Common.

remarks.para: The value returned is at least as large as with an added random fractional interval if is positive or the value returned may be less than for a negative . This is computed via:
remarks.code: baseInterval + Helper.RandTimespan(TimeSpan.FromSeconds(baseInterval.TotalSeconds * fraction));

member.name: T:Neon.Common.ProgramRunner
member.summary: Used to implement unit tests on command line tools by simulating their execution on a thread rather than forking the tool as a process. This is makes debugging easier and also deals with the fact that unit tests may leave orphan processes running.

remarks.para: This class is designed to simulate running a single executable by calling its main entrypoint. To accomplish this, use the default constructor to create a instance. The constructor will set to itself and then you can call to execute the program synchronously (waiting for it to return), or to simulate forking the program by running it on a new thread.
waits to return until the program calls . This is used to ensure that program has completed the activities required by the unit tests before the tests are executed.
remarks.note: Only one instance can active at any particular time.
remarks.para: Simulated program entry points that will be called by and that run indefinitely, need to call when after its started the operation. This returns when the is called. The simulated program should stop any operations being performed, release any important resources and exit cleanly its Main method cleanly.
The dictionary can be used to pass additional arguments into the program being tested. This maps case insensitve keys to object values.
remarks.note: You should call when you're finished with the runner.

summary.para: Executes a program entry point asynchronously, without waiting for the command to complete. This is useful for commands that don't terminate by themselves. Call to kill the running command.
summary.note: IMPORTANT: The simulated entry point must call . This will block until the is called, returning when the program is expected to terminate itself.

member.name: T:Neon.Csv.CsvReader
member.summary: Parses CSV encoded rows from text.

remarks.para: Use this class to parse CSV encoded tables. Use one of the constructors to initialize in instance to read from a file, , string, or a and then call to read each row of the table.
This class handles the all special cases for CSV parsing including quoted fields, escaped double quotes, and fields that include CR and LF characters.
Be sure to call or when you are finished with the class to release any underlying resources.
remarks.note: The underlying stream must support seeking for this class to work properly.

member.name: T:Neon.Csv.CsvTableReader
member.summary: Used to read a CSV table that includes row headers.

remarks.para: This class makes it easy to process tabular data loaded from a CSV file, where the first row of the file contains the row header strings that identify the table columns.

Initialize an instance by passing a , stream, string, or file path to the constructor. The constructor will read the first row of the file and initialize the dictionary which maps the case insensitive column name to the zero based index of the column in the table.

You'll process each data row by calling . This returns a list with the next row of data or null if the end of the table has been reached. You can process the row data returned directly or use the method to access a column value on the current row directly.
remarks.note: This class is tolerant of blank or duplicate column names. In the case of duplicates, the first column matching the requested column name will be used when parsing data.
remarks.para: Applications should call the reader's or method when they are finished with the reader so that the underlying will be closed as well, promptly releasing any system resources (such as the stream).

member.name: T:Neon.Csv.CsvTableWriter
member.summary: Used to generate a CSV table.

remarks.para: This class is used to generate a CSV table with column headers with the class handling the mapping of column names to columns. The class is easy to use. Simply construct an instance, passing an array of case insensitive table column header names and then write table rows by calling Set() methods to set row cell values and then to write each row to the output.

summary.para: Returns the version of the Neon.ModelGen assembly that generated this code plus the generated code schema version. This is formatted like:

where SCHEMA-VERSION is the Neon.ModelGen assembly version and SCHEMA is a simple integer schema version number. The version will be incremented if or when the code generated by future versions of the Neon.ModelGen assembly changes enough to become incompatable with older versions of the Neon.Xunit.XunitExtensions.ValidateController() method. This is likely to never change, but future proofing is always a good idea.

member.summary: Non generic interface describing an entity that can be persisted to a database. See for more information.

member.name: M:Neon.Data.IPersistableType.GetKey

summary.para: Returns the Couchbase or other database key to be used to persist or retrieve the entity. By convention for Couchbase, this key includes the entity type plus the unique key formatted like entity-type::unique-key. For example:

This identifies the document as a user with unique ID as 122330. Document IDs are formatted like this so that we'll be able to take advantage of document filtering by type when we've enabled Couchbase cross datacenter replication.

member.returns: The database key for the entity.

member.name: P:Neon.Data.IPersistableType.__T
member.summary: Identifies the entity type.

member.name: T:Neon.Data.IPersistableType`1
member.summary: Generic interface describing an entity that can be persisted to a database.
member.typeparam: Specifies the data type being persisted.

remarks.para: All entities must implement the property such that it returns the bucket unique string that identifies the entity type. This string will be used to distinguish entity types within a Couchbase bucket.

This interface supports the related concepts of entity key and ref. The entity key is the string used to persist an entity instance to Couchbase. By convention, this string is generally prefixed by the entity type and then is followed by instance specific properties, a UUID, or a singleton name.
Entity ref is the value that other entities can use to reference an entity instance. This could be the same as the entity key but typically without the entity type prefix for brevity,
As a convention, many implementations also have a static GetKey(...) method that returns the Couchbase key for an entity based on parameters passed.

summary.para: Defines the interface for the client used to communicate with the Neon Assistant or a custom service. These services provides access to user and workstation specific settings including secrets and general properties. This is used for activities such as CI/CD automation and integration testing. This solves the following problems:

item.para: Gaining access to secrets. neonFORGE has standardized on 1Password for password management and the Neon Profile Service abstracts the details of authenticating with 1Password and accessing secrets.

This interface supports two kinds of secrets: passwords and values. These are somewhat of an artifact of how we implemented this using 1Password. Secret passwords are values retrieved from a 1Password item's password field and secret values correspond to a 1Password item value field. We found this distinction useful because 1Password reports when passwords are insecure or duplicated but we have other secrets where these checks can be distracting. Custom implementation can choose to follow this pattern or just treat both types of secret the same.
You can also obtain a specific property from a secret password or value by using this syntax:

This is useful for obtaining both the username and password from a login, or all of the different properties from a credit card, etc. This blurs the difference between secret passwords and secret values a bit but we're going to retain both concepts anyway.

Profile values are also supported. These are non-secret name/value pairs used for describing the local environment as required for CI/CD. For example, we use this for describing the IP addresses available for deploying a test neonKUBE cluster. Each developer will often need distict node IP addresses that work on the local LAN and also don't conflict with addresses assigned to other developers.
neonFORGE's internal implementation simply persists profile values on the local workstation as a YAML file which is referenced by our profile service.

list.item: Abstracting access to the user's master password. neonFORGE has implemented an internal Windows application that implements a profile service that prompts the developer for their master 1Password, optionally caching it for a period of time so the user won't be prompted as often. This server also handles profile and secret lookup.

summary.para: implementations should implement caching of secret and profile values and should enable this by default. Callers can disable caching by setting to false and the cached can be cleared via

The Neon.Deployment.ProfileClient implementation communicates with the neon-assistant to retrieve profile values and secrets. neon-assistant manages profile values directly but communicates with 1Password.com to obtain secrets, which can take a second or two. Caching will improve performance and also take some load off of 1Password.

remarks.para: The is used to submit requests to the Neon Assistant application running on the local workstation including retrieving the user's master 1Password, secrets, as well as user profile values.

member.name: T:Neon.Diagnostics.LoggerCreatorDelegate
member.summary: Defines the function used to return custom logger implementations.
member.param: The case sensitive logger event source module (defaults to null).

Optionally specifies a target . This can be useful for redirecting the ourput of a text logger to a file or somewhere else. This parameter may be ignored for non-text based loggers or for other logger specific reasons.
Optionally specifies additional information that can be used to identify context for logged events. For example, the Neon.Cadence client uses this to record the ID of the workflow recording events.

Optionally specifies a filter predicate that overrides the parent filter (if any) used for filtering log entries. This examines the and returns true if the event should be logged or false when it is to be ignored. All events will be logged when this is null.

Optionally specifies a function that will be called at runtime to determine whether to event logging is actually enabled. This overrides the parent function if any. Events will be logged for null functions.

member.name: T:Neon.Diagnostics.ILogManager
member.summary: Describes an application log manager implementation. is a reasonable implementation for many situations but it's possible for developers to implement custom solutions.

remarks.para: Neon log managers are used to manage one or more instances that handle logging for parts of your application, we refer to as modules. By convention, a module is often the fully qualified name of the .NET type doing the logging but this is just a string and can be set to anything. Log managers are responsible for mapping modules to loggers, potentially caching these loggers for performance, and then submitting events to these loggers to be recorded.

Log managers also maintain a long count of the events emitted by the application. This counter is used to record the index of the event in the stream of application events. This index is typically one-based and is useful for knowing the strict order that events were actually recorded. Event timestamps often don't have enough resolution accomplish this.
Log managers provide the property which can be used to control which events are actually recorded. for information about the relative lof levels.

Log managers typically provide a default implementation. defaults to logging events to STDERR as text via which is suitable for many server applications, espectially for those deployed as containers where this is standard behavior. also implements the delegate as an easy way to support custom loggers in your application without having to implement a custom as well.

member.name: M:Neon.Diagnostics.ILogManager.Reset
member.summary: Intended to reset the log manager to its default condition. Implementations may cxustomize what this actually does but the default implementation resets its emitted event counter to zero, clears and cached loggers, and resets the delegate.

member.name: P:Neon.Diagnostics.ILogManager.Name
member.summary: Returns the log manager's name. This can be useful for debugging the log manager itself. This defaults to null.

member.name: P:Neon.Diagnostics.ILogManager.Version
member.summary: The version of the current program or null if not known. This should be formatted as a valid when not null.

member.name: P:Neon.Diagnostics.ILogManager.LogLevel
member.summary: Specifies the level required for events to be actually recorded.

member.name: M:Neon.Diagnostics.ILogManager.SetLogLevel(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the log level by safely parsing a string.

remarks.para: This method recognizes the following case insensitive values: CRITICAL, SERROR, ERROR, WARN, WARNING, INFO, SINFO, INFORMATION, TRANSIENT, DEBUG, or NONE.
remarks.note: INFO will be assumed if the parameter doesn't match any of the values listed above.

member.name: P:Neon.Diagnostics.ILogManager.EmitTimestamp
member.summary: Controls whether timestamps are emitted. This defaults to true.

member.name: P:Neon.Diagnostics.ILogManager.EmitIndex
member.summary: Controls whether the index field is emitted. This is a counter start starts at zero for each application instance and is incremented for each event emitted to help reconstruct exactly what happened when the system time resolution isn't fine enough. This defaults to true.

member.name: M:Neon.Diagnostics.ILogManager.GetNextEventIndex

member.returns: The event index or -1 if = false.

remarks.para: implementations can choose to ignore this delegate when creating loggers. The default implementation does honor this as an easy for applications to change the loggers without having to go to the trouble of implementing and registering an new implementation.

member.name: T:Neon.Diagnostics.LogActivity
member.summary: Used to help log correlate lower-level operations with a higher-level activity.

remarks.para: This structure is intended to help operators and developers correlate lower-level operations with higher level activities that may span multiple systems and services.

The essential idea is to associate a globally unique ID with a high-level activity and then include this ID along with events logged by the various systems and services that participate in the activity. Ultimately, the logged events with the activity IDs will make it to Elasticsearch or some other log database where activaty events potentially spanning many systems can be correlated and analyzed.
An activity ID is simply a globally unique ID string. IDs generated by this class are a currently stringified but IDs may take other forms so, don't depend on this.
In general, activity IDs are passed from service to service via the HTTP X-Request-ID request header (defined by ).

To use this type, call the static method to create a new activity or to associate an instance with an existing activity. Then use the various logging methods to emit log events what will include the activity ID.

member.name: F:Neon.Diagnostics.LogActivity.HttpHeader
member.summary: Names the HTTP header used to hold the activity ID used to correlate operation requests with a higher-level activity.

member.summary: Creates a log activity with a new globally unique ID.

member.summary: Creates a log activity with the ID specified.

member.summary: Returns the activity ID.

member.name: T:Neon.Diagnostics.LogLevel
member.summary: Enumerates the possible log levels. Note that the relative ordinal values of these definitions are used when deciding to log an event when a specific is set. Only events with log levels less than or equal to the current level will be logged.

member.name: F:Neon.Diagnostics.LogLevel.None
member.summary: Logging is disabled.

member.name: F:Neon.Diagnostics.LogLevel.Critical
member.summary: A critical or fatal error has been detected. These errors indicate that a very serious failure has occurred that may have crashed the program or at least seriousoly impacts its functioning.

member.name: F:Neon.Diagnostics.LogLevel.SError
member.summary: A security related error has occurred. Errors indicate a problem that may be transient, be recovered from, or are perhaps more serious.

member.name: F:Neon.Diagnostics.LogLevel.Error
member.summary: An error has been detected. Errors indicate a problem that may be transient, be recovered from, or are perhaps more serious.

member.name: F:Neon.Diagnostics.LogLevel.Warn
member.summary: An unusual condition has been detected that may ultimately lead to an error.

member.name: F:Neon.Diagnostics.LogLevel.SInfo
member.summary: Describes a non-error security operation or condition, such as a a successful login or authentication.

member.name: F:Neon.Diagnostics.LogLevel.Info
member.summary: Describes a normal operation or condition.

member.name: F:Neon.Diagnostics.LogLevel.Transient
member.summary: Indicates a transient error, typically logged by a implementations.

member.name: F:Neon.Diagnostics.LogLevel.Debug
member.summary: Describes detailed debug or diagnostic information.

Applications that do use dependency injection can obtain this by default via .

member.name: M:Neon.Diagnostics.LogManager.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.String,System.Func{Neon.Diagnostics.LogEvent,System.Boolean},System.Func{System.Boolean},System.IO.TextWriter,System.String)
member.summary: Default constructor.
member.param: Indicates that the LOG-LEVEL environment variable should be parsed (defaults to true).
Optionally specifies the semantic version of the current program. This can be a somewhat arbitrary string that matches this regex: "[0-9a-zA-Z\.-_/]+". This defaults to null.

Optionally specifies a filter predicate to be used for filtering log entries. This examines the and returns true if the event should be logged or false when it is to be ignored. All events will be logged when this is null.
Optionally specifies a function that will be called at runtime to determine whether to event logging is actually enabled. This defaults to null which will always log events.
Optionally specifies the logr manager's name. This can be useful when debugging the log manager itself.
Optionally specifies the output writer. This defaults to .

member.name: M:Neon.Diagnostics.LogManager.CreateLogger(System.String,System.IO.TextWriter,System.String,System.Func{Neon.Diagnostics.LogEvent,System.Boolean},System.Func{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Uses the function to construct a logger for a specific source module..
member.param: The case sensitive logger event source module (defaults to null).
Optionally specifies additional information that can be used to identify context for logged events. For example, the Neon.Cadence client uses this to record the ID of the workflow recording events.

Optionally overrides the manager's log filter predicate. This examines the and returns true if the event should be logged or false when it is to be ignored. All events will be logged when this is and the managers filter is null.

Optionally specifies a function that will be called at runtime to determine whether to event logging is actually enabled. This overrides the parent function if any. Events will be logged for null functions.

member.summary: Clears any events recorded by all instances that recorded anything in the current process.

summary.para: Returns the events logged by any instances that recorded anything in the current process. The events will be returned in the order they were logged.
summary.note: This method returns a copy of all of the events, so this isn't really suitable for production.

member.returns: An array with copies of the recorded events.

member.name: M:Neon.Diagnostics.TestLogger.#ctor(Neon.Diagnostics.ILogManager,System.String,System.IO.TextWriter,System.String,System.Func{Neon.Diagnostics.LogEvent,System.Boolean},System.Func{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: The parent log manager or null.
Optionally identifies the event source module or null.
Optionally specifies the output writer. This is ignored for the .
Optionally specifies additional information that can be used to identify context for logged events. For example, the Neon.Cadence client uses this to record the ID of the workflow recording events.

Optionally specifies a filter predicate to be used for filtering log entries. This examines the and returns true if the event should be logged or false when it is to be ignored. All events will be logged when this is null.
Optionally specifies a function that will be called at runtime to determine whether to event logging is actually enabled. This defaults to null which will always log events.

remarks.para: The instances returned will log nothing if is passed as null.

note.para: ASP.NET is super noisy, logging three or four INFO events per request. There doesn't appear to an easy way to change this behavior, I'd really like to recategorize these as DEBUG to reduce pressure on the logs.

member.summary: Extension methods for .

member.name: M:Neon.IO.IStaticDirectoryExtensions.Zip(Neon.IO.IStaticDirectory,System.String,System.String,System.IO.SearchOption,Neon.IO.StaticZipOptions)
member.summary: Creates a ZIP file, including the selected files from the static directory.
member.param: Path to the output ZIP file.
Optionally specifies a file name pattern using standard file system wildcards like [*] and [?]. This defaults to including all files.
Optionally perform a recursive search. This defaults to .

Additional options that control things like whether the files are zipped within the parent directory or whether the files are assumed to contain UTF-8 text and that Windows style CRLF line endings are to be converted to Linux compatible LF endings. You can combine options by bitwise ORing them. This defaults to .

member.name: M:Neon.IO.IStaticDirectoryExtensions.Zip(Neon.IO.IStaticDirectory,System.IO.Stream,System.String,System.IO.SearchOption,Neon.IO.StaticZipOptions)

member.param: Optionally specifies a file name pattern using standard file system wildcards like [*] and [?]. This defaults to including all files.
Optionally perform a recursive search. This defaults to .

Additional options that control things like whether the files are zipped within the parent directory or whether the files are assumed to contain UTF-8 text and that Windows style CRLF line endings are to be converted to Linux compatible LF endings. You can combine options by bitwise ORing them. This defaults to .

remarks.note: The current implementation loads the files into memory so this isn't really suitable for zipping very large files.

member.name: T:Neon.IO.BlockStream
member.summary: Implements an in-memory stream based on a collection of buffers rather than a single byte buffer. This is more efficient than for large streams and also avoids allocations in the large object heap.

remarks.note: Buffer array streams cannot be greater than or equal to 2GiB in length.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a zero length stream with default block size.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a stream of the specified size using the default block size.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a stream of the specified size using the specified block size.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a stream of the specified size using the specified block size and offset.
member.param: Bytes to be reserved at the beginning of each new block.
member.remarks: See for more information on the value and use of the blockOffset prarmeter.

member.summary: Constructs a stream from the blocks passed.
member.remarks: The stream size will be set to the size of the blocks.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.#ctor(Neon.Common.Block[])
member.summary: Constructs a stream from the blocks passed.
member.remarks: The stream size will be set to the size of the blocks.

member.summary: Constructs a stream from a byte array.

member.name: P:Neon.IO.BlockStream.CanRead
member.summary: Returns true if the stream supports read operations.

member.name: P:Neon.IO.BlockStream.CanWrite
member.summary: Returns true if the stream supports write operations.

member.name: P:Neon.IO.BlockStream.CanSeek
member.summary: Returns true if the stream supports seek operations.

member.name: P:Neon.IO.BlockStream.Length
member.summary: Returns the current size of the stream in bytes.

member.name: P:Neon.IO.BlockStream.Position
member.summary: The current stream position.

remarks.note: It is valid to set a stream position beyond the current end of the stream. The stream will be extended to this position. The contents of the extended portion will be undefined.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.SetLength(System.Int64)
member.summary: Sets the length of the stream.
member.remarks: The stream will be truncated if the new length is less than the current length. The stream will be extended if the new length is greater than the current length. In this case, the contents of the extended portion will be undefined.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.SetLength(System.Int64,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets the length of the stream.
member.param: true to modify the underlying block array if necessary.
member.remarks: The modifyBlocks parameter specifies whether the underlying block array will be truncated or extended to the length specified.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.ReadByte
member.summary: Reads a byte from the current stream position, advancing the position by 1.
member.returns: The byte read or -1 if the end of the stream has been reached.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads bytes from the current stream position, advancing the position past the data read.
member.param: Offset where the read data is to be copied.
member.returns: The number of bytes actually read.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.ReadAsync(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Asynchronously reads from the stream.
member.param: Offset where the read data is to be copied.
member.returns: The number of bytes actually read.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.WriteByte(System.Byte)
member.summary: Writes a byte to the current stream position, advancing the position by 1.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes bytes to the stream at the current position, advancing the position past the data written.
member.param: Offset of the first byte to write.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.WriteAsync(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Asynchronously writes bytes to the stream at the current position, advancing the position past the data written.
member.param: Offset of the first byte to write.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.Flush
member.summary: Flushes any stream buffers.
member.remarks: This is a NOP for this implementation.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.Seek(System.Int64,System.IO.SeekOrigin)
member.summary: Moves the current stream position relative to the specified origin.
member.returns: The stream position after the seek.
member.remarks: It is valid to seek past the current stream length. In this case, the stream will be extended with the contents of the extended portion being undefined.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.Append(Neon.Common.Block)
member.summary: Appends a block to the end of the underlying BlockArray.

remarks.para: The underyling block array's SetExactSize() method will be called before appending the block. The stream position will be set to the end of the stream before the method returns.
This method is a performance improvement over writing the a buffer to the stream via one of the write methods.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.Append(Neon.Common.BlockArray)
member.summary: Appends a block array to the end of the underlying BlockArray.
member.remarks:
The underyling block array's SetExactSize() method will be called before appending the block. The stream position will be set to the end of the stream before the method returns.
This method is a performance improvement over writing the a buffer to the stream via one of the write methods.

member.summary: Returns the underlying buffer array.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.ToArray
member.summary: Assembles a contiguous a byte array from the underlying buffer array.

member.name: M:Neon.IO.BlockStream.ReadBlocks(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns requested bytes from the underlying block array as as a new block array.
member.param: The nunber of bytes to read.
member.returns: A new block array referencing the requested bytes in the same underlying buffers as managed by then stream.
member.remarks:
This provides a high performance way for code that knows how to handle block arrays to extract a portion of a stream.
The array returned will be truncated to the length of the underlying stream. The stream position will be advanced past the requested bytes.

summary.para: Describes a logical file in a static file system. This is used to abstract access to static files read from an assembly's embedded resources or potentially from other sources using Linux style paths.
This is currently used to emulate a tree of and instances loaded from an assembly's embedded resources via the extension method.

member.name: T:Neon.IO.PreprocessReader
member.summary: Preprocesses text returned by a by removing comments, expanding variables, and implementing simple conditionals.

remarks.note: This class only implements , , , and . The other methods will throw a .
remarks.para: The processor removes comment lines from the text returned. A comment line starts with zero or more whitespace characters followed by "//".
remarks.note: Comment lines are indicated by a "//" prefix by default but this can be modified via and .
remarks.para: The processor implements simple macro definition and conditional statements. These statements are identifying by a line with the pound sign (#) as the first non-whitespace character.
remarks.note: The processor statement character defaults to the pound sign (#) but can be changed by setting .
remarks.para: The following processing statements are supported:

description.para: Defines a normal variable and setting an optional value. The empty string will be set by default. These variables can be referenced in processing statements or normal text lines as $<name>.
Variable names are case sensitive and may include letter, number, dash, period, and underscore characters.
By default, defined variables may be referenced like $<name> and environment variables like $<<name>>.
Conditionally includes text up to the next #else or #endif statement. The following expressions are supported:
The comparisions are performed after any variables are expanded. The values are trimmed on bothe ends and the string comparision is case sensitive.

item.description: This can optionally be used within an #if statement to include lines when the condition is false.
Provides an easy to conditionally include statements for multiple conditions. The subsequent #case and #default statements up to the next #endswitch statement will be processed.
This command causes the lines up to the next #case, #default, or #endswitch to be outputed if the value matches that specified for the parent #switch statement.

This command causes the lines up to the next #endswitch to be outputed if the value wasn't matched by any of the previous case statements.
#default must appear after all #case statements.

remarks.para: Normal variables can be defined within the source text itself using the #define command described above and variables may also be added in code using . These variables can be referenced as $<name>. Environment variables are also supported. These are referenced as $<$lt;name>>.
remarks.note: You may encounter situations where the default ways of referencing variables conflicts with the syntax of the underlying source text being processed. In these cases, you can set to or to change the format.
remarks.para: Variables are always expanded in #if and switch statements and are expanded by default in the other source lines. Variables are expanded using the ${NAME} syntax by default. The syntax can be modified by setting . Variable expansion can be disabled by setting =false.
remarks.note: By default, the reader will throw a if an undefined normal variable is encountered. This behavior can be modified by setting to a non-null string. In this case, undefined variable references will always be replaced by the value set. defaults to null.

By default, the reader will throw a if an undefined environment variable is encountered. This behavior can be modified by setting to a non-null string. In this case, undefined environment variable references will always be replaced by the value set. defaults to null.
remarks.para: Processing can also be customized via the , , , , , , and properties.
This class can integrate with a implementation added to . This provides a way to abstract access to secrets and profile values from an external source. Three item types are supported:

description.para: Secret passwords are often protected by a password manager. neonFORGE has standardized internally on 1Password for example. Passwords are often required to satisfy complexity and other rules.

Passwords are named by a string and are often persisted to a named location. 1Password stores to secrets in vaults. You'll need the password name and optionally, its location when referencing a password value.
You may also request a specific secret property using an array syntax like:
Doing this overrides the default password property.

Secret values are often protected by a password manager. neonFORGE has standardized internally on 1Password for example. Secret values are similar to passwords but the typically don't comply with complexity or other requirements.

Secret values are named by a string and are often persisted to a named location. 1Password stores to secrets in vaults. You'll need the value name and optionally, its location when referencing a password value.
You may also request a specific secret property using an array syntax like:
Doing this overrides the default value property.

Profile values are string name/value pairs that include non-secret definitions for the user, workstation, or overall environment such as the LAN. These can come in handy when implementing CI/CD where each server/user can be assigned unique profile values that reference specific test endpoints, etc. This is quite powerful.
Profile values are simply named by a string. There is currently no concept of a source, like secrets have.

remarks.para: Secrets and profile values can be referenced via $<$lt;<type:name[:source]>>> where type is one of password, secret (value), or profile and name identifies the secret or profile value and source optionall specifies the secret source (this is ignored for profile values).
remarks.code: $<$<$<password:my-password;my-vault>>> # password from specific source $<$<$<password:my-password>>> # password from default source $<$<$<secret:my-secret;my-vault>>> # secret from specific source $<$<$<secret:my-secret>>> # secret from default source $<$<$<secret:my-secret[username]>>> # retrieve [username] from secret $<$<$<secret:my-secret[password]>>> # retrieve [password] from secret $<$<$<profile:my-profile>>> # profile value
remarks.para: This class will throw when it encounters a secret/profile reference and there no injected implementation or if the implementation has trouble communicating with the profile server. This class also also throws a when a named secret or profile value doesn't exist.

member.name: T:Neon.IO.PreprocessReader.ConditionalType

member.name: P:Neon.IO.PreprocessReader.AngleVariableExpansionRegex
member.summary: A variable expansion that matches normal variables like $<test>, environment variables like <<test>>>, and profile references like <<$lt;secret:my-secret:my-vault>>>> You can set the property to this value to change the behavior.

member.name: P:Neon.IO.PreprocessReader.CurlyVariableExpansionRegex
member.summary: A variable expansion that matches normal variables like ${test}, environment variables like ${{test}} and profile references like ${{{secret:my-secret:my-vault}}}. You can set the property to this value to change the behavior.

member.name: P:Neon.IO.PreprocessReader.ParenVariableExpansionRegex
member.summary: A variable expansion that matches normal variables like ${test}, environment variables like $((test)) and profile references like $(((secret:my-secret:my-vault))). You can set the property to this value to change the behavior.

member.name: P:Neon.IO.PreprocessReader.DefaultVariableExpansionRegex
member.summary: The default variable expansion that matches normal variables like $<test>, environment variables like <<test>>>, and profile references like <<$lt;secret:my-secret:my-vault>>>> You can set the property to this value to change the behavior.

summary.para: Implements a that operates on a section of a parent stream. The parent stream must be able to .

summary.para: Used to have the Neon.Xunit.XunitExtensions.ValidateController<T>() method including the tagged method when validating the service controller against its definining interface. This is useful for rare situations where a service controller inherits from another class that implements some endpoints.
summary.note: By default, Neon.Xunit.XunitExtensions.ValidateController<T>() only considers service methods implemented directly in the service controller during validation.

member.name: T:Neon.ModelGen.DataModelAttribute

summary.para: Optionally specifies the type identifier that will be used by generated code to identify the object type at runtime. This will be used when deserializing the object.

This defaults to the fully qualified name of the type as it appears in the source assembly as it is scanned by the code generator. You may want to set this to reduce the length or just to customize how your data is persistedd.

summary.para: Used to customize the database related code generated for the tagged data model interface.

By default, a public static string GetKey(param object[] args) method is included in generated entity classes so that a database key for a specific entity can be easialy obtained. This method simply generates a string by calling on all of arguments or using "NULL" for null values which each of these being separated by a single colon and then prepending the entire thing with the entity type. The generated code will look something like this:

member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: Optionally specifies the name to be used for the generated service client class. This defaults to the tagged controller class name with a "Controller" suffix being stripped off if present.

param.name: group
param.para: Optionally specifies that the methods from this controller should be grouped together in a generated controller class composed from multiple service controllers. Set this to the name to be used for the client property under which these methods will be generated.
param.note: must also be specified when is set.

summary.para: Returns the name to be used for the generated client class and for transmitting requests to the server or null if the name is to be derived from the tagged class name.
summary.note: The tagged controller class name will be used as the default name, stripping "Controller" off the end of the class name if present.

summary.para: Optionally used to group multiple methods from different controllers with the same together into the same generated service client class or subclass.

This defaults to null which means that the service methods from the different controllers will be generated directly within the generated service client. When this is not null or empty, a subclass using this name with "Client" appended will be generated with the methods from the controllers with this group name.

member.name: T:Neon.Net.JsonClient
member.summary: Implements a light-weight JSON oriented HTTP client.

remarks.para:
Use , , , , , , or
to perform HTTP operations that ensure that a non-error HTTP status code is returned by the servers.

Use , , , , , , or
to perform an HTTP without ensuring a non-error HTTP status code.
This class can also handle retrying operations when transient errors are detected. Customize and/or by setting a implementation such as or .
remarks.note: This class initializes to a reasonable by default and to . You can override the default retry policy for specific requests using the methods that take an as their first parameter.

note.para: The class can be used to customize both the Content-Type header and the actual payload uploaded with POST and PUT requests. This can be used for those special REST APIs that don't accept JSON payloads.

All you need to do is construct a instance, specifying the value to be used as the Content-Type header and the payload data as text or a byte array and then pass this as the document parameter to the methods that upload content. The methods will recognize this special type and just send the specified data rather than attempting to serailize the document to JSON.

member.name: T:Neon.Net.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: This namespace defines which makes calling REST APIs easier as well as a handful of other network related utilities provided by and .

member.name: T:Neon.Net.NetConst
member.summary: Network related constants.

summary.para: The default message transmission unit that is commonly configured across the internet. This is the size in bytes of the largest packet including all of the protocol headers from OSI layers 3 and above. This does not include the data link (e.g. Ethernet) overhead.
Packets larger than this may need to be fragmented (if allowed) to be transmitted end-to-end across several connected networks.

member.name: F:Neon.Net.NetConst.VXLANHeader
member.summary: The size of VXLAN headers in bytes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_Extensible_LAN is a protocol used in cloud and other virtualization environments to scale and separate network traffic between multiple tenants. Network traffic is empasulated in UDP packets with a header added to that identifies the virtual network. This constant specifies the header overhead in bytes.

member.name: F:Neon.Net.NetConst.IPHeader
member.summary: The size in bytes of an IP packet header.

member.name: F:Neon.Net.NetConst.TCPHeader
member.summary: The size in bytes of all headers (IP and TCP) added to a TCP packet.

member.name: F:Neon.Net.NetConst.ICMPHeader
member.summary: The size in bytes of an ICMP packet header.

member.name: M:Neon.Net.NetHelper.ModifyLocalHosts(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Net.IPAddress},System.String)

summary.para: Used to temporarily modify the hosts file used by the DNS resolver for testing, debugging or other purposes.
summary.note: WARNING: Modifying the hosts file will impact all processes on the system, not just the current one and this is designed to be used by a single process at a time.

member.param: A dictionary mapping the hostnames to an IP address or null.

param.name: section
param.para: Optionally specifies the string to use to mark the hostnames section. This defaults to MODIFY which will delimit the section with # NEON-BEGIN-MODIFY and # NEON-END-MODIFY. You may pass a different string to identify a custom section.
param.note: The string passed must be a valid DNS hostname label that must begin with a letter followed by letters, digits or dashes. The maximum length is 63 characters.

remarks.note: This method requires elevated administrative privileges.
remarks.para: This method adds or removes a temporary section of host entry definitions delimited by special comment lines. When is non-null and non-empty, the section will be added or updated. Otherwise, the section will be removed.
You can remove all host sections by passing both and as null.

member.summary: Lists the names of the local host sections.
member.returns: The section names converted to uppercase.

member.summary: Parses an IPv4 endpoint from a string.

member.name: M:Neon.Net.NetHelper.GetUnusedTcpPort(System.Net.IPAddress)
member.summary: Returns a free TCP port for a local network interface.
member.exception: Thrown when there are no available ports.

note.para: The behavior when is called multiple times without actually listening on the ports is somewhat undefined.

We believe most operating systems won't return the same port again for a while (perhaps a few minutes) so you're probably safe retrieving a few unused ports before using them for testing and other non-production purposes.

Production code should begin listening on and unused ports immediately after retrieving one. This will ensure that the unused ports returned will be unique and also help avoid having another application grab the port before you have a chance to listen on it.

member.name: M:Neon.Net.NetHelper.GetRoutableIpAddress
member.summary: Returns a routable (non-loopback) IPv4 address for the current machine.
member.returns: The IP address or null if there doesn't appear to be a connected network interface.

remarks.para: This works via a somewhat fragile heuristic. We list all network interfaces, filter out those that are loopback, TAP interfaces, Hyper-V switches as well as any that aren't up and then return the highest speed interface from any remaining interfaces.
This may not work as expected for machines with multiple active connections to different networks.

member.name: M:Neon.Net.NetHelper.GetNetworkConfiguration
member.summary: Returns basic information about the current network connection including the machine's routable IP address, the network CIDR and gateway as well as the DNS server addresses.
member.returns: A with the information or null when the computer doesn't appear to be connected to a network.
member.remarks: This implementation is somewhat fragile because it relies on which uses heuristics to try to identify a suitable connected network. This may not work as expected for machines with multiple active connections to different networks.

remarks.note: This class currently supports only IPv4 addresses.

member.name: T:Neon.Net.Pinger
member.summary: Implements a threadsafe subset of the .NET Framework class.

remarks.para: Unfortunately, the .NET Framework class is not threadsafe (even the async methods). So, we need to ensure that only one ping request is performed on any given instance.

My original idea was to simply create and dispose ] instances on the fly for each request, but I changed my mind after thinking about the potential performance overhead as well as the potential for exhausting ephemeral socket ports.
Instead, I'm going to maintain a queue of instances that that can be reused for subsequent queries.

member.name: T:Neon.Retry.ExponentialRetryPolicy
member.summary: Implements an that retries an operation first at an initial interval and then doubles the interval up to a limit for a specified maximum number of times.

remarks.para: You can enable transient error logging by passing a non-empty logCategory name to the constructor. This creates an embedded using that name and any retried transient errors will then be logged as warnings including [transient-retry] in the message.
remarks.note: Only the retried errors will be logged. The final exception thrown after all retries fail will not be logged because it's assumed that these will be caught and handled upstack by application code.
remarks.para: Choose a category name that can be used to easily identify the affected component. For example, couchbase:my-cluster to identify a specific Couchbase cluster.

member.name: M:Neon.Retry.ExponentialRetryPolicy.#ctor(System.Func{System.Exception,System.Boolean},System.Int32,System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.String)
member.summary: Constructs the retry policy with a specific transitent detection function.
member.param: Optionally specifies the function that determines whether an exception is transient (see ). You can pass null if all exceptions are to be considered to be transient.
Optionally specifies the maximum number of times an action should be retried (defaults to 5).
Optionally specifies the initial retry interval between retry attempts (defaults to 1 second).
Optionally specifies the maximum retry interval (defaults to essentially unlimited: 24 hours).
Optionally specifies the maximum time the operation will be retried (defaults to unconstrained)
Optionally enables transient error logging by identifying the source module (defaults to null).

remarks.para: The parameter defaults to -1 indicating that the operation should be attempted up to 5 times, unless a is specified. In this case, will be ignored and the timeout will be honored.
When is greater than or equal to zero and is passed, then both and will be honored, with retries stopping when either are exceeded.

member.name: P:Neon.Service.ServiceEndpoint.PathPrefix
member.summary: This specifies the path prefix to prepended to URIs accessing this service. This defaults to an empty string. This has meaning only for the HTTP and HTTPS protocols.

remarks.note: Any leading forward slash character will be stripped when setting this.

summary.para: This specifies the network port to be used for URIs accessing this service. This defaults to -1 which indicates that HTTP and HTTPS based endpoints will be initialized to their default ports 80 and 443 so you don't need to specify and explicit ports for these. You will need to set this to a valid port for TCP and UDP protocols.
summary.note: CAUTION: It's best not to rely on this value when setting up your service network endpoints and reference the port from instead because that will always be a valid TCP port number.

member.summary: ASP.NET services, this can be set to the metadata used for Swagger documentation generation related purposes. This defaults to null.

member.name: P:Neon.Service.ServiceEndpoint.Uri

summary.para: Returns the URI for the endpoint. For HTTP and HTTPS endpoints, this will include the service hostname returned by the parent , along with the port and path prefix. For TCP and UDP protocols, this will use the tcp:// or udp:// scheme along with the hostname and just the port. The path prefix is ignored for TCP and UDP.
When is -1 for HTTP or HTTPS endpoints, the URL returned will use the default port for thbe protocol (80/443). For TCP and UDP protocols, the port must be a valid (non-negative) network port.
summary.note: For production, this property returns the partially qualified hostname for the host, omitting the cluster domain (e.g. cluster.local). Use if you need the fully qualified URI.

member.exception: Thrown when is not valid for the endpoint protocol.

member.name: P:Neon.Service.ServiceEndpoint.FullUri

summary.para: Returns the URI for the endpoint. For HTTP and HTTPS endpoints, this will include the service hostname returned by the parent , along with the port and path prefix. For TCP and UDP protocols, this will use the tcp:// or udp:// scheme along with the hostname and just the port. The path prefix is ignored for TCP and UDP.
When is zero for HTTP or HTTPS endpoints, the URL returned will use the default port for thbe protocol (80/443). For TCP and UDP protocols, the port must be a valid non-zero network port.
summary.note: For production, this property returns the partially qualified hostname for the host, including the cluster domain (e.g. cluster.local. Use if you need the relative qualified URI.

member.exception: Thrown when is not valid for the endpoint protocol.

member.summary: Implements an async/await friendly equivalent of .

remarks.para: This class can be used to grant a task exclusive access to a resource. This class is pretty easy to use. Simply instantiate an instance and then call within a using statement:
remarks.note: Be very sure to include the await within the using statement to avoid hard to debug problems. The await ensures that the using statement will dispose the acquired lock as opposed to the that returns the lock.
remarks.para: Applications that cannot use a using statement may release the lock explicitly by disposing the object returned by the lock method, like this:
's method ensures that any tasks waiting for a lock will be unblocked with an .

IMPORTANT: This class does not allow a single task to acquire the lock more than once. This differs from how the regular classes work which do allow a single thread to acquire the mutex more than once.
This means that you cannot expect to acquire a mutex in a task and then call into a method that will also attempt to acquire the same mutex. Doing this will result in a deadlock.
You can use instead.

member.name: T:Neon.Tasks.AsyncPeriodicTask
member.summary: Implements a common asynchronous coding pattern where an asynchronous operation is performed periodically and cancellation and exceptions are handled cleanly.

remarks.para: This class provides a nice way to implement the very common server side pattern where we need to periodically perform some operation until the operation signals that it's done or the task is canceled, while handling some of the messy exception handling details.
You'll use the constructor to create a task, passing the task interval, asynchronous task handler and optional exception handler and cancellation token and then call to execute the task.

will call the task handler, wait for the interval and then repeat. The task handler return false to continue running or true to signal that should stop. also monitors the cancellation token passed and watches for thrown by the task handler to stop itself.

The exception handler will be called for all exceptions thrown by the task handler except for exceptions as these signal that should terminate. Exception handlers return false to continue running or true to signal that should stop. stop.
Finally, an optional handler can be specified that will be called just before the terminates.
remarks.note: This class implements and the task will be terminated when this is called.

member.name: T:Neon.Tasks.AsyncReaderWriterLock
member.summary: Implements an async/await friendly equivalent of ReaderWriterLock.

remarks.para: This class can be used to grant a single writer task exclusive access to a resource or multiple reader tasks. This class is pretty easy to use. Simply instantiate an instance and then call or within a using statement:
remarks.note: Be very sure to include the await within the using statement to avoid hard to debug problems. The await ensures that the using statement will dispose the acquired lock as opposed to the that returns the lock.
remarks.para: Applications that cannot use a using statement may release the lock explicitly by disposing the object returned by the lock method, like this:
's method ensures that any tasks waiting for a lock will be unblocked with an .
This class is implemented is fairly simple and always favors writers over readers. Also, all waiting readers will be released together.
remarks.note: does not support any kind of reentrant locking support. Child tasks will be considered to be completely independent of the parent and will not inherit the parent's lock and a single task will not be able to acquire the same lock multiple times.
