member.name: T:Neon.Tasks.SyncContext
member.summary: Used by public async library methods to reset the current task so that continuations won't be marshalled back to the current thread which can cause serious problems for UI apps.

remarks.para: This class was adapted from this blog post:
I renamed the structure, converted it into a singleton and added an optional call and a global mode to tune the operation for server vs. UI applications.

The async/await pattern is more complex than it seems because the code after the await may run on the same thread that performed the await in some circumstances (e.g. for UI applications) or on another thread in other environments. Library code needs to adapt to both situations.

UI platforms like WinForms, WPF, UXP,... require that all user interface manipulation happen on the UI thread and the synchronization context in these cases will be configured to have all awaits default to continuing on the calling (typically UI) thread to make it easy for developers to await a long running operation and then update the UI afterwards.

The problem for UI applications is that if the awaited operation internally awaits on additional operations (which is quite common), then each of the internal operations will also continue on the UI thread. This can be big problem because there's only one UI thread and continuing on the UI thread means that the operation needs to be queued to the application's dispatcher possibly leading to serious performance and usability issues.

This is less of a problem for console and server apps where awaited operations generally continue on any free threadpool thread, but scheduling can be customized so this isn't necessarily always the case.

As the blog post linked above describes, developers are encouraged to call , passing false for every async call where the result doesn't need to be marshalled back to the original synchronization context. Non-UI class libraries typically don't care about this. The problem is that to do this properly, MSFT recommends that you call Task.ConfigureAwait(false) on EVERY async call you made in these situations. This is pretty ugly and will be tough to enforce on large projects over long periods of time because it's just too easy to miss one.

It's also likely that async library methods will be called serveral, perhaps hundreds of times by applications and it's a shame to require application developers to call everywhere rather than somehow having the library APIs handle this.

This struct implements a custom awaiter that saves the current synchronization context and then clears it for the rest of the current method execution and then restores the original context when when the method returns. This means that every subsequent await performed within the method will simply fetch a pool thread to continue execution, rather than to the original context thread. To accomplish this, you'll simply await at or near the top of your async methods:

The global property controls what the method actually does. This defaults to which turns into a NOP which is probably suitable for most non-UI applications that reduce overhead and increase performance.
UI applications should probably set the which prevents nested method continuations from running on the UI thread and also ensures that any initial synchronous code won't run on the UI thread either.

This example sets the mode and then awaits HelloAsync() which clears the sync context and then performs a long running synchronous operation and then two async operations. Note how all of the continuations in HelloAsync() after the clear are running on a background thread but the continuation after await HelloAsync() is back to running on the UI thread.
This is pretty close to being ideal behavior.

member.name: P:Neon.Tasks.SyncContext.Clear
member.summary: await this singleton to clear the current synchronization context for the scope of the current method as a potential performance optimization. The original context will be restored when the method returns.

remarks.para: You'll typically at or near the top of your method. This will look something like:
remarks.note: is not a method.
remarks.para: Awaiting this property clears the current synchronization context such that the subsequent async calls will each marshal back to threads obtained from the thread pool and due to the compiler's async magic, the original synchronization context will be restored before the HelloAsync() method returns.

The property controls what awaiting actually does. This defaults to which is probably suitable for most non-UI applications. UI applications will probably want to explicitly set to help keep continations off the UI thread, which is often desirable.

summary.para: Used to control what actually does. This defaults to which is probably suitable for most non-UI applications by reducing task overhead. UI application will probably want to set to keep work from running on the UI thread.
This defaults to for server code, because we're writing more server applications than UI applications these days.

summary.para: Enables `await SyncContext.Clear;` such that the continuations within the nested scope of the method will not happen on the original thread.
This mode is the default and is generally suitable for server and other non-UI applications.

Enables `await SyncContext.Clear;` such that the continuations within the nested scope of the method will not happen on the original thread and that the awaitee can immediately release the current thread for other uses.
This mode is useful for UI applications because it ensures that any synchronous operations won't be executed on the original thread.

member.name: T:Neon.Time.GoDuration
member.summary: Implements support for GO Language formatted durations. This class is useful for integrating with GO applications.

note.para: measures time down 1 nanosecond resolution whereas 's resolution is 100ns and both implementations use a signed 64-bit integer as the underlying representation. This means that can represent of maximum duration of about 290 years (positive and negative) where can handle about 29,000 years.
This class will throw a when converting a that is beyound the capability of a .

remarks.para: The input is a possibly signed sequence of decimal numbers, each with optional fraction and a unit suffix, such as "300ms", "-1.5h" or "2h45m". Valid time units are "ns", "us" (or "s"), "ms", "s", "m", "h".
remarks.note: GO timespans are limited to about 290 years (the maximum number of nanoseconds that can be represented in a signed 64-bit integer).

member.name: T:Neon.Time.PolledTimer
member.summary: Implements a timer suitable for use in scenarios that need to poll periodically to see if an action needs to be performed.

remarks.para: A common programming pattern is to have background threads check periodically for something to do; like resend a message, clean up idle connections, or signal a timeout. The class provides an easy way to encapsulate the interval and next scheduled time at which these events should happen.

Use or to create a timer, specifying the firing interval. The second constructor also specifies the autoReset parameter which indicates that the timer should automatically reschedule itself after being fired. Note that one of these constructors must be used. structures created with the default constructor will thow a when an attempt is made to use it.

While being constructed, a polled timer calculates its next scheduled firing time (SYS). Note that this value generated by not a normal system time. The scheduled firing time is available as the property. Ther current interval is available as the property.

Use to determine if the timer has been fired. This will return true if this is the case. If autoReset=true was passed to the constructor, then will automatically reset the timer by scheduling the next firing time. If autoReset=false, then the timer will remain in the fired state until is called.
Asynchronous applications may find it more convienent to call to wait for the timer to fire.

The , , and methods are used recalcuclate the firing time. The first variation schedules this time as the current time plus the timer interval. The second variation schedules the timer for immediate firing (typically used right after the timer is constructed in situations where the application wishes the timer to fire right away the first time it is polled), and the third method resets the timer to fire at a random interval between zero and the timer's interval (useful when trying to avoid having multiple timers fire at the same time).

The method prevents the timer from firing until is called or is set. This is useful for preventing a timer from firing when an operation initiated from a previous firing is still executing (perhaps on another thread).

member.name: T:Neon.Time.RecurringTimer
member.summary: Used to manage tasks that need to be performed on a periodic basis.

remarks.para: This timer is designed to be polled periodically from an application's background thread by calling the or methods. These methods will return true if the action associated with the timer is to be performed.

This class works by watching for the transition between a call to made at a time before the scheduled event and then a subsequent call made when the current time is at or after the scheduled event time. will return true on the subsequent call if the time is right.
This behavior ensures that scheduled tasks will only be executed once for any recurring schedule, even if the application is restarted.
The method uses the current UTC time to perform the time comparison. The will use the time passed (which may be local time, etc.) to do this.

note.para: This timer auto resets after returns true. Note also that must be called fairly frequently (on the order of a few minutes or less) to obtain reasonable accuracy.
Asynchronous applications may find it more convienent to call to wait for the timer to fire.

The and methods may be used to explicitly reset the timer to fire at the next scheduled time. This may be useful for ensuring that short duration timers are properly reset after an operation that may take longer to complete than the timer interval.

remarks.para: Recurring timers are represented as strings with the format of the string depending on the type of timer. The table below describes these formats:

description.para: Disabled timers never fire. Simply place the word Disabled at the beginning of the timer string.
Minute timers fire at the top of every minute. There is no offset. Minute timers are formatted as:
Quarter hour timers are fired four times an hour at the offset from the 15 minute time. Quarter hour timers formatted as:
Hourly timers are fired once per hour at the offset from the top of the hour. Hourly timers are formatted as:
Daily timers are fired once per day at the specified time of day. Daily timers are formatted as:
Interval timers are fired on a regular interval that is not not tied to a specific period. Interval timers are formatted as:

member.name: T:Neon.Time.SysTime
member.summary: A date/time implementation that is guaranteed to be monotonically increasing even as the underlying system time is updated manually or automatically to adjust for daylight savings time or clock skewing.

remarks.para: Use of system time rather than real-time is useful in situations where events need to be timed in relative rather than absolute time. Using absolute time to measure intervals call can be problematic because system clock may be have to be periodically corrected to keep it in sync with a global time base. These corrections will cause event timers to become inaccurate.
The property returns the current system time and calculates and returns an essentially infinite timespan value that will be safe when added to the current system time.
remarks.note: The instances returned by this class are useful only for measuring timespans. The Day, Month, Year properties will have no useful meaning.

The class is implemented such that the first time returned by the property will be a time value that is a minumim of one year after . This is useful in situations where programs want to schedule a periodic event for immediate triggering when the application starts by setting the last trigger time to .
remarks.para: The class is also capable of maintaining rough synchronization with an external time source. To use this feature, you'll periodically get the time from the external source and assign it to the static property then you can use the property to get and estimate of the current external time.

The local side clock will likely drift over time, resulting in a skew between the time returned by and the actual time at the external source. This skew can be limited by getting the external time and assigning it to more frequently.
remarks.note: The time returned by is not guaranteed to be monotimically increasing since reported times may jump around as the bias between the local and external clocks are adjusted.
remarks.para: This class is currently implemented using the Windows GetTickCount() API. This function returns the number of milliseconds since the operating system was booted with a resolution equal to the process/threading timeslice (typically 10-15 milliseconds). The actual resolution for the current machine can be obtained from .
The counter is an unsigned 32-bit value and will wrap-around every 49.7 days. The class handles this by using a to wake up every five minutes to check for and handle this wrap-around.

As noted above, the time value returned by has no relation to the actual calendar date. The first date returned after booting the computer will be approximately 1/1/0002 00:00:00, one year greater the minimum value. returns a calculated value that when added to will result in a date one year less then the maximum value.

These one year offsets were choosen so that applications can perform reasonable offset calculations (e.g. within background tasks) without fear of wrap-around. Since and span up to 10,000 years, this means that calculations will remain valid for up to 9,998 years after the computer has been started, which should be good enough for most applications.

member.summary: Size of physical memory available, in bytes.

member.name: F:Neon.Windows.MEMORYSTATUSEX.ullTotalPageFile
member.summary: Size of the committed memory limit, in bytes. This is physical memory plus the size of the page file, minus a small overhead.

member.name: F:Neon.Windows.MEMORYSTATUSEX.ullAvailPageFile
member.summary: Size of available memory to commit, in bytes. The limit is ullTotalPageFile.

member.name: F:Neon.Windows.MEMORYSTATUSEX.ullTotalVirtual
member.summary: Total size of the user mode portion of the virtual address space of the calling process, in bytes.

member.name: F:Neon.Windows.MEMORYSTATUSEX.ullAvailVirtual
member.summary: Size of unreserved and uncommitted memory in the user mode portion of the virtual address space of the calling process, in bytes.

member.name: F:Neon.Windows.MEMORYSTATUSEX.ullAvailExtendedVirtual
member.summary: Size of unreserved and uncommitted memory in the extended portion of the virtual address space of the calling process, in bytes.

member.name: T:Neon.Windows.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: This namespace defines low-level Windows P/Invoke mappings as well as a simply class that can execute PowerShell commands.

summary.para: A simple proxy for executing PowerShell commands on Windows machines.
summary.note: This class requires elevated administrative rights.

member.name: P:Neon.Windows.PowerShell.PwshPath
member.summary: Optional path to the Powershell Core pwsh executable. The PATH environment variable will be searched by default.

member.name: M:Neon.Windows.PowerShell.GetPwshPath
member.summary: Returns the path to the Powershell Core pwsh executable.

member.name: M:Neon.Windows.PowerShell.#ctor(System.Action{System.String},System.Action{System.String})
member.summary: Default constructor to be used to execute local PowerShell commands.
member.param: Optionally specifies an action to receive logged output.
Optionally specifies an action to receive logged error output.
member.exception: Thrown if we're not running on Windows.
member.remarks: You can pass callbacks to the and/or parameters to be receive logged output and errors. Note that will receive both STDERR and STDOUT text if isn't specified.

member.summary: Executes a PowerShell command that returns a simple string result.
member.param: Optionally disables that environment variable subsitution (defaults to false).
member.exception: Thrown if the command failed.

member.name: M:Neon.Windows.PowerShell.ExecuteJson(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Executes a PowerShell command that returns result JSON, subsituting any environment variable references of the form ${NAME} and returning a list of dynamic objects parsed from the table with the object property names set to the table column names and the values parsed as strings.
member.param: Optionally disables that environment variable subsitution (defaults to false).
member.returns: The list of dynamic objects parsed from the command response.
member.exception: Thrown if the command failed.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Contracts.Covenant
member.summary: A simple, lightweight, and partial implementation of the Microsoft Dev Labs Contract class.

remarks.para: This class is intended to be a drop-in replacement for code contract assertions by simply searching and replacing "Contract." with "." in all source code. In my experience, code contracts slow down build times too much and often obsfucate async methods such that they cannot be debugged effectively using the debugger. Code Contracts are also somewhat of a pain to configure as project propoerties.
This class includes the , and methods that can be used to capture validation requirements in code, but these methods don't currently generate any code.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Contracts.Covenant.Requires(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Verifies a method pre-condition.
member.param: An optional message to be included in the exception thrown.
member.exception: Thrown if is false.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Contracts.Covenant.Requires``1(System.Boolean,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Verifies a method pre-condition throwing a custom exception.
member.typeparam: The exception to be thrown if the condition is false.
member.param: The first optional string argument to the exception constructor.
The second optional string argument to the exception constructor.

remarks.para: This method throws a instance when is false. Up to two string arguments may be passed to the exception constructor when an appropriate constructor exists, otherwise these arguments will be ignored.

member.summary: Asserts that a condition is true.
member.param: An optional message to be included in the exception thrown.
member.exception: Thrown if is false.

member.summary: extensions.

member.name: M:System.DateTimeExtensions.RoundUp(System.DateTime,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary:
Rounds a up to the nearest specified interval.
var date = new DateTime(2010, 02, 05, 10, 35, 25, 450); // 2010/02/05 10:35:25 var roundedUp = date.RoundUp(TimeSpan.FromMinutes(15)); // 2010/02/05 10:45:00
member.param: The time interval to be rounded to.

member.name: M:System.DateTimeExtensions.RoundDown(System.DateTime,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary:
Rounds a down to the nearest specified interval.
var date = new DateTime(2010, 02, 05, 10, 35, 25, 450); // 2010/02/05 10:35:25 var roundedDown = date.RoundDown(TimeSpan.FromMinutes(15)); // 2010/02/05 10:30:00
member.param: The time interval to be rounded to.

member.name: M:System.DateTimeExtensions.RoundToNearest(System.DateTime,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary:
Rounds a to the nearest specified interval.
var date = new DateTime(2010, 02, 05, 10, 35, 25, 450); // 2010/02/05 10:35:25 var roundedToNearest = date.RoundToNearest(TimeSpan.FromMinutes(15)); // 2010/02/05 10:30:00
member.param: The time interval to be rounded to.

member.name: M:System.Reflection.NeonAssemblyExtensions.GetResourceFileSystem(System.Reflection.Assembly,System.String)
member.summary: Returns an eumlated static file system that includes some or all of an assembly's embedded resources. This method returns the root for the file system.

param.name: resourcePrefix
param.para: Specifies the resource name prefix to be used to identify the embedded resources to be included in the static file system. See the remarks for more information.

remarks.para: This method maps Linux style paths (using forward not back slashes) to embedded resources in the assembly. Resources in .NET projects are embedded and named like:
where ASSEMBLY-NAME is the name of the source assembly, DIR optionally specifies the directoriea to the resource and RESOURCE-FILENAME specifies the name of the resource file.

When a .NET project is built, any source files with build actions set to Embedded Resource will be included in the assembly using the naming convention described above. The ASSEMBLY-NAMESPACE will be set to the source projects default namespace and the DIRs will be set to the relative path from the project file to the source resource file. For example, if your project is structured like:
remarks.code:
my-project/ my-project.csproj
top-level.txt resources/ resource1.dat resource2.dat tests/ test1.txt test2.txt samples/ sample1.txt sample2.txt
remarks.para: and its default namespace is company.mproject, then the following resources embedded in your project assembly:
remarks.code: company.my-project.top-level.txt company.my-project.resources.resource1.dat company.my-project.resources.resource2.dat company.my-project.resources.tests.test1.txt company.my-project.resources.tests.test2.txt company.my-project.resources.samples.sample1.txt company.my-project.resources.samples.sample2.txt
remarks.para: By default, calling on your project assembly will return a with a directory structure holding all of the resources. The paths are mapped from the resource names by converting any dots except for the last one into forward slashes.
remarks.code: / company/ my-project/ top-level.txt resources/ resource1.dat resource2.dat tests/ test1.txt test2.txt samples/ sample1.txt sample2.txt
remarks.para: You can also pass an optional resource name prefix so that only a subset of the resources are included in the file system. For example, by passing company.my-project.resources, file system returned will look like:
remarks.code: / resource1.dat resource2.dat tests/ test1.txt test2.txt samples/ sample1.txt sample2.txt
remarks.para: When creating the file system from resource names, it's possible to encounter situations where it's not possible to distingish between a a directory and a file name. For example:
remarks.code: company.my-project.resources.resource1.dat
remarks.para: Here are some possibilities:

list.item: path is /company.my-project.resources.resource1 and the file name dat
path is /company.my-project.resources and the file name resource1.dat
path is /company.my-project and the file name .resources.resource1.dat

remarks.para: There is really no way for this method to know what the original resource source files and directory paths were. To resolve this, we're going to assume that resource file names include a file extension with a single dot and that any additional dots will form the file's parent directory path.
remarks.note: All resource file names must include an extension to be loaded properly. If you need a file to be loaded without an extension, save the file with the special "._" extension like test._. This method will remove that special extension when reading files with it.
remarks.para: What this means is that your resource file names must include a file extension. So, file names like this are OK:
remarks.code: schema.sql config.json
remarks.para: You should avoid file names like:
remarks.code: schema.1.sql
remarks.para: and use something like a dash instead so that schema won't be considered to be part of the file's parent directory path:
remarks.code: schema-1.sql

member.name: M:System.RandomExtensions.RandomTimespan(System.Random,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Returns a random between zero and a specified maximum.
member.remarks: This method is useful for situations where its desirable to have some variation in a delay before performing an activity like retrying an operation or performing a background task.

member.name: M:System.RandomExtensions.RandomTimespan(System.Random,System.TimeSpan,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a between the specified base interval plus a random period of the specified fraction of the value.
member.param: The fractional multiplier for the random component.

remarks.para: The value returned is at least as large as with an added random fractional interval if is positive or the value returned may be less than for a negative . This is computed via:
remarks.code: baseInterval + RandTimespan(TimeSpan.FromSeconds(baseInterval.TotalSeconds * fraction));
remarks.para: This method is useful for situations where its desirable to have some variation in a delay before performing an activity like retrying an operation or performing a background task.

member.name: T:System.WeakEventController
member.summary: Implements a weak event listener that allows the owner to be garbage collected if it is the only remaining link is an event handler.

remarks.para: This class is intended to be a drop-in replacement for the WeakEventManager class that is available in .NET 4.5 but is not currently present in the Xamarin Mono class libraries. Use the and to add or remove event handlers.
remarks.note: Important: Take care to remove any handlers when an event listener instance is disposed and/or finalized. Neglecting to do this will orhpan the objects uses to track the handler references.
remarks.para: This code was adapted from a Code Project article by Samuel Cragg called WeakEventManager for WinRT. The code is licensed under the The Code Project Open License (CPOL).
I enhanced the code by making it threadsafe.

member.name: F:System.WeakEventController.registeredEventBuckets
member.summary: We're going to assign events to buckets using the hash of their property values. Each bucket will hold a list of the weak events that were dropped in the bucket. This should improve scalability when there are a lot of events.
